title: How many hours does a music producer usually put into making a song? - Quora

response.answer_text: Many Pros take much less time than you think… If the song is well thought out… composed for ‘production’ it could be 1 to 3 days in the studio. Then again they usually KNOW what they can count on… engineer - mixer - masterer - equipment - talent performance - etc. But most pros I knew… never tried to really fix it in the mix… they knew what they were after and how to get it. And that was it. I really believe on producing a song in your head WHERE you know you can get those sounds… if you can’t you should have a plan b? Top line wealthy Producers… don’t have a problem usually. I mean if you take the best with the best then it usually comes out real good. For run of the mill producers who don’t have the talent or expertise or equipment available it can be a real struggle - but it can be fun. If you are a one man show… things are much different too. You can spend a year on a song…

Writing as someone who does music production/recording/composing as a hobby, more than I should. I spent probably 100+ hours on my band’s last song only to get to the end and being thoroughly unhappy with the result and deciding to start all over again. I have been doing this with the goal of reaching the professional quality level for 6 years. Our last EP (4 songs) took me 4 years to complete and it’s nowhere near what one would call professional. My tip to all those treading the same road is, GET IT RIGHT IN THE RECORDING STAGE! You’ll spent countless hour trying to save something that cannot be saved in the production just because the mic was 2 inches to the left and was getting a lot of resonance from the guitar, or the singer’s bracelet tingling as she sang , or the hum from the computer, etc. Anyway, getting better everyday… (I hope!)
